captions.text: Hey! Do you guys want to come grab food with a big group of people terrified of eating alone.
Hey I'm your room mate. Please don't be lame as shit.
We're gonna be best friends, until we find people we actually have something in common with.
Oh I care way more about getting fucked up than going to class.
I'm trying really hard to seem cooler than I was in high school and... It's not working.
My side of the room is way cuter than yours.
Our room's going to smell like weed... a lot.
I'm politely offering to switch beds with you although we both know I'm not going to do it.
Oh I'll do anything I can to avoid confrontation. We're going to be spending an unfortunate amount of time together.
Hey, our parents already left so we're acting like hot shit. Come on!
Once we start rushing frats I'll definitely stop hanging out with you.
I'm only being nice to you because you have a fake I.D.
This is my first time away from home and I'm actually terrified.
I checked you out on Facebook, and your sister is really hot! I will hit on her when she visits.
I'm trying to sleep with every girl I meet this week.
We're going to hook up once and then we'll avoid eye contact for the four years.
I am never going to clean this comforter. Maybe if I puke on it but probably still not.
This is my boyfriend. We're going to sex aisle you all the time.
I'm going to resent the fuck out of that.
I'll never tell you when somethings bothering me, but I will be extremely passive aggressive about it.
Hooking up with you will be the first mistake I make in college but definitely not the last.
This room is kinda miserable but I'm 18 and absolutely anything is better than living with my parents.
Oh I'm on scholarship so I'm only paying 20 grand to get fucked up.
Remember what I look like now because I'm going to gain 15 pounds.
I'm going to bring back a ton of frat boys and I don't really care if you're in here.
I'll pretend to be sleepin and hate every second of it.
Also I'm huge 'N Sync fan... No Strings Attached changed my life.
Hi! I'm going to pursue you sexually.

title: If College Freshmen Were Honest On Move-In Day

comments.author: xXxFairBeautyxXx

comments.text:
Although I got along great with my freshman roommate (we're still best 
friends and have an apartment together) I'm not gonna lie. I am the passive 
aggressive friend. Exactly as she said in the video "I'll never tell you 
when something's bothering me" but I will get extremely moody over it. 
However I personally do it because I know I'm making a bigger deal out of 
something so I just don't bring it up, but that doesn't stop it from 
pissing me off to the extreme. But I'm skilled enough to keep my roommate 
oblivious to my anger long enough to the point where I eventually let go 
and forget about it. It's very rare for me to actually get to the point 
where I 'unleash.' So far it's only happened once. I'm planning on keeping 
it that way. (Don't take this the wrong way, I do not blame my roommate for 
anything, I just get angry at ridiculous stuff...)﻿
comments.author: squidy2343

comments.text:
Hello you anxious seniors going into college for the very first time! 
Congratulations, you made it! Do not fright over what is going to happen at 
the dorms, its really just how you make of it. If you want a fun time at 
the dorms, just have a fun time! (Do NOT blast music at 4AM, unless you're 
okay with getting complaints and enemies) There are so many things that I 
want to list, but its basically just life. Its a place to stay until you're 
done with college, basically. You are NOT the only person who feels alone 
and insecure at the dorms. Just try to talk to someone. Everyone I've met 
is friendly. If you have questions, just reply and I will try my best to 
answer them asap. I have finals.﻿

It really depends on how you grew up. If you've never had to share a room 
you might be super passive aggressive with a new roommate that you have to 
share a TINY bedroom with and a bathroom with an entire floor. If you were 
super sheltered and had your parents manage most of your life yeah, you 
might party too much your first semester and get bad grades. These are 
stereotypes but they are super common. The freshmen 15 is real just because 
they force freshmen to eat in the dining hall (they don't have access to a 
kitchen), and most of the healthy food tastes awful.﻿

comments.author: Cruz Den

comments.text:
+Hugo Patino-Cano I was 17 when I started college too. I guess it also 
depends on whether or not you live on campus. I was super anti-social in 
high school. I had social anxiety, depression, and I'm an introvert 
already. I never touched alcohol in high school and was too scared to smoke 
weed. I did finally try smoking it near the end of my senior year though. 
When I got to college though, that changed. My first semester, I smoked 
like crazy but never drank. Second semester was both, but not too much. 
It's probably because I had never done it, so I used it all in excess when 
I was finally able to. College changes you. It may not make you a drug 
addict but things will change and you might end up trying things you never 
in a million years thought you'd try. I have done many things that people 
would never expect from the high school-me. I'm not saying you should do 
drugs or drink, It's perfectly understandable to not want to right now. 
It's not for everyone. But just remember to have fun.
comments.author: Cruz Den

comments.text: +Hugo Patino-Cano I guess.
comments.author: James Carter

comments.text:
+James Carter But who gives a shit? There are no "I should have done this" 
in life, because what is done is done and there is nothing you can do 
about. You are stuck with the decision you made at that time. I'm making 
this decision at this moment, will I regret it in the future? It's 
possible. Can I do anything to change that? No. This is how I feel at this 
moment, and for me that's all that matters. I don't care what happens in 
the future, I should only worry about right now because that is the only 
thing that is important. I shouldn't think about the future, because 
chances are it won't go the way you are thinking. So forget about all that 
and worry about right now, how you feel right now. And I know all of this 
sounds extremely unnecessary, but it is my defense into why I'm making this 
decision and not caring for "what if I regret it."

comments.author: BadgerCheese94

comments.text:
*Things I Wish Someone Had Told Me When I Was Entering University*

These are based on my personal experience (and that of people I know 
directly). 

1. Once you have the necessary basic courses done, *take the harder courses 
within your first two years if possible* - if you’re applying to grad 
school they’ll usually look at only the grades of the last two years. (In 
Canada, anyways - don’t take my word on that for other countries!)

2.*If your university has multiple campuses, don’t assume courses are 
transferable just because the campus is part of the same university.*  I 
know, it makes no sense, but most of the time they don’t actually transfer. 
Check with your advisor first.

3. *Always get everything your advisor tells you in writing.* That way if 
the information they gave you was wrong you have a way of proving the 
mistake was not on your end.

4. a) *If you can, take a course during the Spring and one during the 
Summer semester.* That way you can take one less class during the normal 
semester and make your life a bit easier. You usually end up with a week or 
two between semesters anyway, so it’s not like you’ll have no vacation 
whatsoever.

b) *If you can, make it a class you know you’ll need to take at some point 
but you know you’re likely to struggle in/have more work assigned;* that 
way you only have the one class to focus on and you can actually do well on 
it instead of barely scraping by.

c) *Don’t take more than one class per semester in the spring/summer 
semesters.* One a semester is more than manageable. Two is insanity, 
because they’re compressed courses. 

5. *Always save screenshots of any and all payments you make online, 
regardless of whether you get an email receipt.* If it gets sent to the 
wrong place or there’s some internal error you’ll have a copy to show as 
proof of payment.

6. *Do your best on the little assignments.* They’re a great grade cushion 
for the big tests. If you go to a small university (or attend small 
classes), it will also show your professor that you’re a responsible 
student, so if you have a problem with handing in something on time in the 
future they’ll be more likely to be lenient and understanding.

7. *Back up everything. Always. Without fail. Don’t put it off for even a 
day.*

8. *Use resources available to you for help.* If your school has a writing 
centre, use it. Even if you just want someone to help you get your essay 
planning in order, look over your final copy of a paper, or to look over 
the bibliography to make sure it’s ok.

9. *If you have the books or readings before class starts, get ahead on 
notes and reading as much as possible.* ‘Cause once the semester starts, 
ain’t nobody got time for that.

10. *Start on your essays as soon as possible, even if it’s just choosing a 
topic and doing preliminary research.* Later on in the semester when due 
dates and exams pile up it’ll save you a world of grief.

11. *Don’t bother to make perfect citations as you write, but make sure you 
have a way of knowing where the citation came from.* You never know what 
you’re gonna cut out in the end, so taking the time to make perfect 
citations as you write your essay is a waste of time; but you need to have 
some way of knowing where it came from so you’re not having to hunt it down 
later. I usually just use a keyword I know relates to a certain article (or 
even make a list of which keyword goes with what) and then go back in the 
end and make the citations.

12. As much as I hate doing them, *essay planning actually helps*. It saves 
on a lot of editing later. Dammit.﻿

comments.author: Chirimo

comments.text:
+Kuki Glambert I have a friend whose advisor cost her over $1,000 due to 
wrong advice on what classes she could take. And I ran the risk of not 
getting into grad school due to my advisor not telling me about the 1st (I 
took advanced Spanish, which to me was easy, in my first two years, which 
meant I had 4 A+ grades that didn't go toward my overall grade, while 
having 2 C+s dragging me down), nor did she tell me that classes in the 
other campuses might not apply - if my friend hadn't found this out the 
hard way I would've had no idea (she wasn't told her courses from our 
campus wouldn't transfer to the uni's main campus, so she paid a semester's 
worth of cash - including residence - for nothing).

Yup, this is pretty accurate. Advice for those going into college: 
Don't drink/smoke to excess. Don't binge drink. I will never forget having 
to take a friend to the ER for alcohol poisoning.

Go to class. Seems like a no brainer, but you'd be surprised.

Go to at least one party. If you like that sort of scene, good. If not, 
that's fine too.

Don't expect to become best friends with your first roommate.

Most important: relax. Be yourself. And have fun.﻿

comments.author: Fease Yough

comments.text:
The one with the big group of freshmen eating together is so true. I 
sometimes have eaten with people during the first semester, but it was a 
small group of people (2-4 at most). Or, I would eat with one person if I 
see someone. Otherwise, I sit by myself. I don't mind it because I keep to 
myself in general when in public like that (unless I see people and say 
hello).﻿

comments.text:

comments.text:
i start college this monday , ill tell you how it went later , i have never 
been in college or had college friends or siblings so its a totally new 
expirience , however i dont have high expectations , school was pretty bad 
for me , so im not that optimistic about college , but who knows what 
future holds for me , i may even make some friends.

comments.author: laura paola castro diaz

comments.text:
Oh this is so great.
First year of college I had to live at home, dad was a skinflint.
Second year of college I was making a man's wage working on MBZ cars in 
Manhatten, I paid my way. I was stronger than any of the other kids I knew, 
even the football boys. I threw my roomestuff out the 2nd floor window on 
my third week. His bed was stuffed with condoms. I built motorcycles in my 
room, as I had my apartment I slept in 20 miles away. My GF's had to put up 
with me. My favorite was Lorna Steele, she would do my laundry. I paid her 
way to meet up with her old rich BF. I had more money than the rich kids, I 
worked on MBZ's in Manhatten, I was good, I was the Shop Manager 21.
 worked 40 to 50 hours, and took a full load as a Chem/Phy major.
I did not put up with anyone's crap. It was fun.﻿

comments.text:
Things I'll do in college but almost everyone else didn't/wouldn't do:

Avoid smoking.
Avoid drinking.
Avoid illegal drugs.
Avoid sex (especially too early).
Avoid dating someone I barely know.
Actually try to get A's and B's.
Don't get broke.﻿
comments.author: ElectricPyroclast

comments.text: +ElectricPyroclast gee what a special snowflake
comments.author: Nadda Syafira

comments.text:
+9inchtablet You're right that "everyone does it" doesn't make "it" 
something good. No questions there. I feel like the "all sins are equal" 
clause, though, is a controversial statement. I can lie and say, "Today's 
gonna be clear skies!" and we get partly cloudy weather, but if all sins 
are truly equal, perhaps that's not so different from me raping a young 
child. In my interpretation, I think that committing just one sin makes you 
an impure being, and that is where "all sins are equal": it doesn't matter 
which sin you commit if the only question is how you become impure. 
Weighting the punishment/consequences, that's something totally different. 
An analogy: you have a glass of pure water, but you drop a speck of dust; 
it makes the water no longer pure as adding a handful of dirt would.
comments.author: ElectricPyroclast

comments.text:
+ElectricPyroclast It's possible they didn't, but no one should judge if 
they're not God according to the bible. All I know is that he flat-out said 
it was wrong. Just because everyone does it doesn't make it any less of a 
sin. In Christianity, all sins are equal, something he flat-out said as 
well.
comments.author: 9inchtablet

comments.text:
+9inchtablet Opinions change over time, and I'm aware of that. Which is why 
I'm still a virgin at age 17. Just in case I do eventually change my mind 
and do think fornication is undoubtedly a "capital crime". Under that 
doctrine, though, you can say a lot of so-called Christians that have died 
did not go to heaven.
comments.author: ElectricPyroclast

comments.text:
+ElectricPyroclast But God was pretty clear about the whole "Don't 
fornicate" thing. He literally said "Fornicators do not go to heaven". And 
that was in the new Testament.
comments.author: 9inchtablet

comments.text:
+9inchtablet God has created 2 or 3 Covenants with the Jews (don't exactly 
remember), and he has said many things that were required for them to 
follow. In Christianity, though, that has all changed when Jesus arrived. 
He died to take the burden for all our sins, and it is our job to figure 
out what to do with our new freedoms. Now in the New Testament books 
detailing what happened after Jesus' death and resurrection, we just pretty 
much stop receiving absolute must-do instructions. It is a very strange 
religion with too many possible interpretations, which is why I'm currently 
not affiliated with any church.
comments.author: ElectricPyroclast

comments.text:
+ElectricPyroclast Although according to the bible, God was the one who 
said people who fornicate don't go to heaven.
comments.author: 9inchtablet

comments.text:
+metalangel12311 Oh, you think I'm *that* kind of Christian. Before 
anything, I'll just tell you straight up that about 2/3 of young adult 
Christians want to do premarital sex, even though some think it may be 
sinful. To me personally, I think premarital sex has its good perks: you 
don't end up marrying someone you're sexually incompatible with. Also, the 
Bible is not really a holy book. It's a collection of works written by 
around 40 men in 3 different continents, conglomerated by a group of other 
men sometime after Jesus' death. God's word is God's word. The Bible is 
only a bunch of interpretations of God's word plus some historical context.
comments.author: ElectricPyroclast

comments.text:
I don't care about sin, as I'm not religious. I'm saying that you're being 
a hypocrite when you say that sex with a girlfriend or boyfriend is 
alright, when the bible/quran/whatever 'holy' book you follow forbids you 
to have sex with those you're not married to.
comments.author: metalangel12311

comments.text:
+metalangel12311 You're basically saying sex with anyone is sinful but sex 
with anyone you're not married to is not sinful. That sentence doesn't make 
sense. I respect your opinion and don't plan on changing it, but I'll just 
tell you mine for clarification on how I think: Sex with anyone you haven't 
been friends with for long is not a good idea. It should be saved for 
intimate relationships that have lasted months.
comments.author: ElectricPyroclast

comments.text:
+ElectricPyroclast So you believe that sex with anyone is sinful but 
fornification isn't? You're such a hypocrite. And your 'holier-than-thou' 
attitude is very annoying.
comments.author: metalangel12311

comments.text:
Honestly here's what it boils down to. I don't care if anyone else does any 
of those stuff, I just want to avoid any of the negativities involved in 
any of those activities. If it's a bad idea, my idea is just to avoid doing 
it.

comments.text:

do that? and have fun not getting broke. unless your parents will be 
supporting you, balancing a job AND classes while paying for food and other 
necessities while still treating yourself sometimes isnt as easy as it 
sounds. also, sex isn't something thats shameful.

comments.text:
+Reginald Gickington Yeah smoking tobacco can lead to health-problems, but 
that doesn't mean you have to look down upon people that do smoke. What 
people do with their body is up to them, and is not really any of your 
business. 
Some narcotics have helped people. For example Marijuana for people with 
epilepsy, or autism. Even LSD is a life changing experience, that I'd 
recommend to anyone.

comments.text:
+Anjalee Burrows Didn't say he HAS to drink. But unfortunately for you, 
there is a big drinking culture in university. Yeah you can still go out to 
bars, not drink any alcohol, but you will be surrounded with half-drunk 
friends that will not be able to relate with you.

People commenting should get of their high horse. They are condemning 
drinking, smoking and doing narcotics without having any experience with 
them.
